Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: Carotenoid trade-offs in a species with colorful females: environmental influences and fitness consequences
Award.AbstractNarration: Animals must make economical decisions about how to distribute limiting resources in order to maintain health and survival. The investigators focus on carotenoid pigments, a particularly important and limiting resource in the diets of human and non-human animals. Vertebrate animals cannot synthesize carotenoids and must obtain them from dietary sources which may be available in only limited quantities. Carotinoids they play three important - and sometimes competing - roles in animal physiology. First, carotenoids are directly responsible for many examples of red, orange and yellow coloration in animals, and this coloration is often necessary for attracting mates. Second, carotenoids in the bloodstream or stored in tissue support the immune system. Third, carotenoids are important antioxidants, which protect the body's cells by removing potentially damaging molecules called free radicals. The carotenoid trade-off hypothesis predicts that when dietary carotenoids are limiting, animals will allocate existing carotenoids to whichever tissue type is most beneficial to them at that time. The investigators take a unique approach to exploring this hypothesis by studying carotenoid trade-offs in female, convict cichlids, Amatitlania nigrofasciata, Central American fish in which females - not males - are brightly colored. Females have the added constraint of allocating carotenoids to their eggs to facilitate offspring survival. The investigators will combine laboratory and field research to examine how environmental stressors such as predators and parasites influence carotenoid allocation strategies, and how these strategies impact health, attractiveness, and offspring survival. Because all vertebrate animals rely in some way on carotenoids, this research will provide fundamental insights into how ingesting and properly allocating essential nutrients affects both physiology and reproduction. This proposal includes a significant training component, as both principal investigators will train and mentor undergraduate and graduate students at their institutions. They will also work with Nicaraguan collaborators to increase research infrastructure at a Nicaraguan biological field station and train Nicaraguan students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many animals exhibit stunning color patterns that have captured the attention of scientists and non-scientists alike for centuries, if not millennia.  What is the function of these brilliant colors?  Do they attract mates, deter rivals, or serve both functions simultaneously?  Is color an honest indicator of individual quality?  Might the pigments that contribute to vivid color patterns also serve important physiological functions?  Our research investigates these questions using convict cichlid fish – a species whose females (but not males) boast a bright orange patch on the side of their body. The patch is derived from carotenoid pigments that females obtain from their food (usually vegetation or small invertebrates). These pigments adorn the orange patch and also can boost immune function, contribute to the health and survivorship of eggs and offspring, and serve antioxidant functions.  Our research focused on two main questions: i) what information, if any, does the orange patch communicate?; and ii) if the availability of carotenoids is limited, do females allocate the pigment to the skin and to other physiological functions in ways that would optimize survival and reproduction?

 

We hypothesized that the carotenoid-­based coloration of female convict cichlid fish acts as an advertisement of her quality and that males would prefer to establish a pair bond (partnership) with more colorful females. We conducted rigorous experimental tests that, surprisingly, falsified our hypothesis but revealed a likely alternative. While we often default to thinking about "ornaments" as signals indicating quality to prospective mates, we have uncovered an alternative role in one of the (relatively) few reversed dichromatic species, where females bear vibrant colors. Specifically, we discovered in both field-based and lab-based investigations, that the orange color signals quality to other females. We uncovered evidence that more colorful females are perceived as a greater threat to a male-female pair bond than drab females, and that color is an honest indicator of female body condition (quality); colorful females thus provoke significantly more aggression than drab females.

 

Our field research also suggests that carotenoid pigments might be a limiting resource at small spatial scales in natural environments. Females become relatively drab when defending a nest against predators and competitors. This suggests that the stress of living in such a risky environment coupled with limited availability of carotenoid might drive pigment allocation away from the skin, perhaps to serve important physiological functions. There has been considerable debate about carotenoid limitation in the literature. We have collected a tremendous amount of physiological data from fish in the wild, and these data may shed new light on how females trade off ornamentation for such things as immune function and proper reproduction when carotenoid availability is finite. Finally, our field excursions highlight some of the serendipity of science - particularly the discovery of males that employ female mimicry as an alternative reproductive strategy.  If the data support this hypothesis, it would be one of the first documented cases of alternative reproductive tactics in New World cichlid fishes.
